journal-meta.journal-title: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part E: Journal of Process Mechanical Engineering

title-group.article-title: Approaches for component degradation modelling in time-varying environments with application to residual life prediction

article-meta.aff: State Key Laboratory of Mechanical Systems & Vibration, Shanghai Jiao Tong University, Shanghai, People’s Republic of China

author-notes.corresp: *State Key Laboratory of Mechanical Systems & Vibration, Shanghai Jiao Tong University, 800 Dong Chuan Rd., Shanghai, 200240, People’s Republic of China. email: youmingyi@gmail.com

abstract.p: This article explores two approaches for modelling the effect of time-varying environmental conditions on the degradation processes of systems subject to linear/exponential degradation, and derives the procedures for applying the approaches to real-time residual life prediction. The first approach, namely the look-up table (LUT) approach, accesses the effect of environmental conditions empirically from historical data without artificially imposing any additional term on the classical stochastic linear degradation model, provided that the historical training data covers all possible finite environmental conditions. The second approach, namely the multiplicative acceleration effect (MAE) approach, regards that the environmental condition has a multiplicative acceleration/deceleration effect on component degradation rate, and is applicable to the case when the historical data only partially covers the possible finite/infinite environmental conditions. In approach development, the parameter estimation algorithms are explicitly derived so that the historical training samples with time-varying environmental conditions can be used to estimate the prior distributions of component degradation rate. Several numerical experiments designed based on real degradation data of ball grid array solder joints are conducted to evaluate the proposed approaches. The experimental results verify the superiority of the proposed approaches over the classical approach which simply ignores the effect of environmental conditions. The LUT approach slightly outperforms the MAE approach when they are both applicable. On the other hand, the MAE approach still performs well in presence of new environmental conditions.

sec.title: 1 INTRODUCTION
sec.p: During the years, the dominant maintenance program for critical engineering components/systems (e.g. aircraft gears [1], furnace [2], turbine [3], etc.) has gradually shifted from corrective maintenance (CM), age-based preventive maintenance (PM), to condition-based maintenance (CBM) [4]. CBM is a maintenance program that recommends maintenance actions based on the information collected through condition monitoring. The ‘condition’ usually refers to the sensory signals (e.g. vibration signals [5, 6] and thrust force [7]) that directly/indirectly related to a component’s health state, as well as its operational environmental conditions that influence its degradation process/rate. Compared with the classical age based PM strategy, CBM regards that well-selected sensory signals are better indicators of a system’s health state than its age.

Residual life (RL)/residual life distribution (RLD) prediction is one of the essential elements of a CBM program [4]. The capability of accurate and reliable prognostics can significantly reduce the maintenance cost or improve the average system availability [8–10]. To date, many physics-based or data-driven models for RL/RLD prediction have been reported [4, 11]. However, most of the models are developed based on the assumption that the component’s operationalenvironment does not change over time or it has no impact on the degradation process [12]. Unfortunately, the assumption is usually not true and it is a fact that a component’s operational environment has a significant effect on accelerating or decelerating the rate of its degradation process [13].

There are very limited works that explicitly address the effect of time-varying environmental conditions when predicting a component’s RL/RLD [13–16]. From an accelerated life-testing perspective, Doksum and Hóyland [14] modelled the accumulated damage in material as a Wiener process. Kharoufeh and Cox [15] presented a degradation-based procedure for estimating the full and residual lifetime distribution of a single-unit system. They modelled the cumulative degradation as a cumulative stochastic process, where the degradation rate is a positive function of the Markovian environment with finite space. Further, the degradation rate was considered to be constant under a given environmental condition. Kharoufeh et al. [16] extended their work in reference [15] by considering the case of semi-Markovian environment. Gebraeel and Pan [13] presented a degradation modelling framework for computing components’ RLD in time-varying environments, without imposing any assumption of the environmental evolution. The approach in reference [13] is generally appropriate for components with linear/exponential degradation patterns. Basically, Gebraeel and Pan suggested that the effect of environmental conditions on a component’s degradation is additive and such effect can accumulate over time. Compared with the works in references [14] to [16], the work in reference [13] has the feature that a component’s in situ degradation signals and environmental changes are used to continuously update the prediction of its RLD in a real-time manner.

In light of the above works [13–16], it is necessary to answer two questions for addressing the challenge of environmental effect modeling (EEM). The first question is: How to model the effect of different environmental conditions on the component’s degradation process? To model such effect explicitly as ageing acceleration [14], additive damage accumulation [13], or inexplicitly/empirically by measuring the different degradation rates in the associated environmental conditions [15, 16]? The second question is: Under a given environmental condition, does the component have a deterministic [15, 16] or probabilistic [13] degradation rate? It is valuable to explore some other perspectives on EEM when only very limited related works have been reported.

On the other hand, a large volume of historical training data is necessary for parameter estimation when the effect of environmental conditions is considered [13–16]. Therefore, the availability of the historical training data becomes a non-ignorable concern when choosing EEM method. Most of the related methods are developed based on the concern that the needed historical training data is available or can be collected at a low cost. However, such concern might not be true for complex/precise components. Therefore, it is necessary to give explicit consideration for the availability of historical training data when developing the EEM methods for RL/RLD prediction. Herein, in a degradation model, the historical training data refers to the collected evolution of the historical samples’ age, sensory degradation signals, and the associated environmental conditions.

By the above motivations, this article explores two approaches for EEM of components subject to linear/exponential degradation in time-varying environments, and derives the procedures for applying the approaches to real-time residual life prediction. Explicit concern is given for the availability of historical training data in approach development. The first approach, namely the look-up table (LUT) approach, models the effect of environmental conditions empirically without artificially imposing any additional term on the classical stochastic degradation model, if the historical training data covers all the possiblefinite environmental conditions. The second approach, namely the multiplicative acceleration effect (MAE) approach, regards that the environmental condition has a multiplicative effect on component degradation rate. In both approaches, the component has probabilistic degradation rate under a given environmental condition. Moreover, the in-situ degradation signals and environmental changes are utilized to update the RL/RLD prediction.

The rest of the article is organized as follows: section 2 proposes the LUT approach and the MAE approach, details their implementation procedures from prior distribution estimation of model parameters to online RL prediction. Section 3 evaluates the LUT approach and the MAE approach through several numerical experiments designed based on real degradation data of ball grid array (BGA) solder joints. Finally, section 4 concludes the article.

sec.title: 2 METHODOLOGY
sec.p: This section develops the LUT approach and the MAE approach. Subsection 2.1 outlines a general framework of the proposed approaches and introduces the classical stochastic degradation model that serves as the basis for further development. Subsection 2.2 develops the LUT approach. Finally, Subsection 2.3 develops the MAE approach.

sec.title: 2.1 Framework and preliminary
sec.p:
In this article, both the LUT approach and the MAE approach correspond to a comprehensive framework outlined in Fig. 1. Fig. 1
The framework for the LUT approach and the MAE approach, where ① denotes the parameter estimation algorithm, ② denotes the parameter updating method, and ⋌ denotes the RL/RLD prediction formula

Figure 1 shows that the availability of the historical training data or the feasibility of preparing the needed training data influences the choice of the EEM method, which further decides the functional structure of the degradation model. Afterwards, a parameter estimation algorithm is used to estimate the prior distribution of the model parameters based on the training data. In online implementation phase, a parameter-updating mechanism is used to update the model parameters based on the in situ sensory signals and the environmental conditions of a specific component. Evidence has been collected that statistically more accurate RL prediction can be obtained based on the updating mechanism [5]. After update, the posterior distributions of the model parameters can be used for RL/RLD prediction.

The problem of RL/RLD prediction of components with linear/exponential degradation patterns has been studied extensively [5, 17–19] when the environmental condition is constant. The functional form of a linear stochastic degradation model is [18]

where S(ti) is the value of the degradation signal at time ti, ϕ is the deterministic intercept parameter for each sample, β is the stochastic parameter (degradation rate), and ϵ (ti) is the error term at time ti. The stochastic parameter β is assumed to have a s-normal prior distribution π(β) with mean μβ and variance σβ2. Generally, π(β) represents the characteristics of the population under the given environmental condition and can be estimated from the historical training data. The error term is typically set to be i.i.d. N(0,σɛ2). Note that the linear degradation model can also model the exponentially increasing degradation signals by taking the logarithm of the data points[13].

A component may degrade faster or slower whenenvironmental conditions change [13–16]. Consequently, the environmental condition essentially influence the term βti. Following the idea of [14], acceleration or deceleration of the ageing process ti could be used for EEM. Following the idea of [13], modifying β to be (β + γX) could be used for EEM, where γ is the vector of stochastic parameters and X is the vector of environmental variables (e.g. load and speed). Following the idea of [15, 16], β becomes constant and its value under each environmental condition is estimated empirically based on the historical training data, while the environmental evolution is Markovian or semi-Markovian.
In the following, we detail the proposed LUT approach and the MAE approach, which are different from the above-mentioned methods.

sec.title: 2.2 The LUT approach
sec.p: The LUT approach accesses the effect of environmental conditions empirically from historical training data, without artificially imposing any additional term on equation (1). The prerequisite of applying the LUT approach is that the historical training data ideally covers all the possible finite environmental conditions a component may confront. In addition, statistically many sampling points of the degradation signals under each environmental condition should be available, which are used to estimate the model parameters (μβ, σβ) (i.e. π(β)) under each environmental condition. Afterwards, a LUT can be established, and one can refer to the LUT for the change of π(β) once a change of the environmental condition has been detected.

Let Sji denote the value of the degradation signal of training sample j at time ti, where j = 1,…,M and M is the number of training samples. Let k be the indictor of the environmental conditions, where k = k1,…,kN and N is the number of all possible environmental conditions. Note that an environmental condition could be one environmental variable or a combination of several environmental variables. Also note that, two environmental conditions are different if their indicators are different.

For the purpose of estimating π(β) for each environmental condition k, it is ideal that the degradation signals Sjik of several training samples (e.g. samples j1–jm) are collected under a constant environmental condition throughout their lifetime, where Sjik denotes the value of the degradation signal of training sample j collected under environmental condition k (2) where Nj·Δt is the failure/suspension time of sample j, where Δj denotes the sampling interval length. In such case, the likelihood function for the observed degradation signals under the environmental condition k is [20] (3) where Lk denotes the likelihood function under environmental condition k, βk denotes the probabilistic degradation rate under environmental condition k, ϵji denotes the error term of sample j at time ti, ønor denotes the probability density function (pdf) of a standard normal distribution, and f(βk) denotes the pdf of βk.

However, for components that tend to operate under variable environmental conditions in normal operation, such ideal historical training data may not always be available. In such cases, it is more feasible to estimate (μβk,σβk) based on the training samples which have operated under several environmental conditions in real practice. However, the likelihood function in equation (3) cannot be directly adopted, as the value of the degradation signal at time ti can no longer be modelled by equation (1), but by (4) where Tje denotes the time duration sample j has spent under the environmental condition e, which could be one interval or a summation of several intervals on the timeline. In equation (4), sample j is assumed to pass environmental conditions k1–kn without loss of generality, where kn is the current environmental condition. To obtain the likelihood function, consider the degradation signal at time ti + 1 provided that the environmental condition does not change at time ti + 1
Equation (5) minus equation (4) gives
As ϵj(i + 1) and ϵji are both i.i.d. N(0,σɛ2), we have

Therefore, the likelihood function for the historical training data under the environmental condition k is (8) where δj(i+1)k is the indicator function, where δj(i+1)k=1 if Sj(i + 1) and Sji are both collected under environmental condition k, and δj(i+1)k=0 otherwise. Afterwards, the parameters (μ∧βk,σ∧βk) that maximize equation (8) is the maximum likelihood estimator for (μβk,σβk). By equation (8), (μβk,σβk) can be estimated based on the samples that have operated under several environmental conditions throughout their lifetimes.

Once (μ∧βk,σ∧βk),k=1,…,M have been estimated, the prior distribution π(βk) are fully characterized, and therefore a LUT can be established. In the operation process of an individual sample l, its in situ degradation signals and environmental condition changes are used to update π(βk) for more accurate RL prediction.

Given d sampling points (Sl1,…,Sld), when the environmental condition has not changed since system initialization, that is, 1≤d≤(Tlk1/Tlk1ΔtΔt) in equation (5), the Bayesian rule suggests (9) where the joint distribution of the observations (Sl1,…,Sld) is in the form
Substituting equation (10) and π(βk1) into equation (9) gives the posterior distribution of βk1 [18]

However, if there are environmental condition changes, that is, d>(Tlk1/Tlk1ΔtΔt) in equation (5), the conventional updating mechanism in equation (9) cannot be directly used. Given the current environmental condition kn, only the recent several sampling points under the environment condition kn are responsible for the posterior distribution of βkn (12) where tq corresponds to the first sampling point ofthe most recent sampling points consecutively collected under the environmental condition kn. Therefore (13) where the joint distribution of the observations (Slq,…,Sld) can be calculated in a similar method as in equation (8)
Substituting equation (14) and π(βkn) into equation (13) gives

Note that equations (12) to (15) can also handle the case when no environmental changes occur since tl1. It is also possible that the component operates under the same environmental condition (e.g. kn) in several time intervals before td, which is more complex. Even in such case, we still use the derivations in equations (12) to (15). The rationale is that a sample could have very different degradation rate (i.e. βk) in two disconnected intervals of its lifetime, even with same environmental condition. This is due to the stochastic nature of degradation processes of most engineering components. In cases when it could be justified that the component keeps the same degradation rate under one environmental condition regardless of any interference of other environmental conditions, equation (13) can be readily revised as (16) where (tq1,tq2),…,(tq(m-1),tqm) are also the time intervals of component operation under the environmental condition kn. Then, π(βkn) can be readily derived based on equation (16). However, this is not the focus of the current article, and we adopt the updating mechanism in equation (15).

Once the posterior distribution of π(βkn) has been calculated based on equation (15), the predictive distribution of a future signal at time t + td can still be characterized by a normal distribution [18]. The mean and variance of S(t + td) can be estimated as

Based on the prediction distribution in equation (17), the distribution of RL TR predicted at time td can be computed, such that S(TR + td) = D, where D is the critical level based on operation experience or industrial standards. More specifically, for small σϵ, we have [18] (18) where Φ(·) is the cumulative distribution function (cdf) of a standard normal distribution. It is suggested that the truncated cdf is computed to preclude negative RL [5, 18]
By equation (19), the RL TR can be estimated as the 50th quantile of the RLD, i.e.

Now, each essential element of the LUT approach has been covered. The implementation procedures of the LUT approach can be entirely summarized in Fig.2. The historical training data is used to establish the LUT of the prior distribution π(βk). If the environmental condition keeps unchanged, the collected degradation signals are used to continuously update the model parameters. Whenever a change in the environmental condition has been detected, a new prior distribution from the LUT is picked up, and then the updating mechanism is used, and so on. Note that the LUT approach reduces to the approach in reference [18] if the environmental condition keeps unchanged throughout a sample’s lifetime. Fig. 2
Implementation procedures of the LUT approach

sec.title: 2.3 The MAE approach
sec.p: The LUT approach can handle the case when the historical training data ideally include all the possible finite environmental conditions a component may confront, without any parametric characterization of the effect of environmental conditions. However, it is possible that the historical training data does not cover all the possible cases or there are even infinitely many environmental conditions. In such cases, it is necessary to artificially specify some parametric models for EEM, estimate the model parameters through the available historical training data, and then extrapolate to the case of new environmental conditions. Examples of parametric EEM can be referred to references [13] and [14].

In this article, the effect of environmental conditions is modelled as the multiplicative acceleration/deceleration effect on component degradation rate. Specifically, the prior distribution π(β) which represents the population characteristics is modelled as a s-normal distribution with mean μ0 exp (αX), and variance (σ0 exp (λX)) (20) where μ0 and σ02 are baseline mean and variance, respectively, X = (x1,…,xs)T is the vector of environmental variables, α = (α1,…,αs) and λ = (λ1,…,λs) are vectors of regression coefficients, and s is the number of environmental variables/covariates. μ0 and σ02 can be interpreted as the mean and variance of β when all environmental variables are zero. Note that in equation (20), the idea of EEM is similar as that of the well-known proportional hazards model (PHM) [21]. It is identified that similar idea has been adopted by Zhao et al. [22] in condition-based inspection/replacement policies, while the degradation increment at any inspection point is assumed tobe i.i.d. exponentially distributed. However, very differently, this article considers the problem of RL/RLD prediction and assumes normal degradation increment at any sampling point. The problem of parameter estimation (estimating π(β)) based on the historical training data is also discussed, which is important for practical applications. Further, the problem of parameter updating using in situ degradation signals of each individual component is considered.
To ease the problem of π(β) estimation, a reference environmental condition XR = (x1R,…,xsR) is defined at first
Then, under any environmental condition, we have
Typically, XR can be chosen as the most common environmental condition for component operation.

For π(β) estimation, the common/general case that the historical training samples have operated under several environmental conditions is considered. π(βR) is estimated as the first step. To do this, the derivations in equations (4) to (8) can be directly used, and this leads to the likelihood function (23)

where M, Nj, δj(i+1)k, Sji, Δt hold the same meaning as those in Subsection 2.2. Maximizing equation (23) gives the maximum likelihood estimators (μ∧βR,σ∧βR). The second step is to estimate (α,λ) based on the historical training data under all the environmental conditions. The full likelihood function is

In equation (24), note that when k = R, α(Xk – XR) = λ(Xk – XR) = 0, hence the data under the reference environmental condition does not influence the estimation of (α,λ). Maximizing equation(24)gives the maximum likelihood estimators (α∧,λ∧).
After (μ∧βR,σ∧βR,α∧,λ∧) are estimated, given any encountered or new environmental condition kn, the prior distribution π(βkn) can be estimated as

It is worth mentioning that, by equation (25), even the case of infinite environmental conditions can be handled. And this distinguishes the MAE approach from the LUT approach. However, the price is the necessity of artificially imposing the structure exp[α∧(Xkn-XR)] and exp[λ∧(Xkn-XR)], which may or may not capture the nature of the environmental effect.

Afterwards, given the in situ degradation signals, the updating mechanism of the MAE approach is very similar as that of the LUT approach detailed in equations (12) to (15). Specifically, we have (26) where q and d hold the same meaning as those in subsection 2.2.

The method of calculating the predictive distribution of a future signal S(t + td) is the same as that in equation (17). Also, equation (19) can be adopted for RL/RLD prediction without modifications.

Finally, the implementation procedures of the MAE approach is outlined in Fig. 3. Fig. 3
Implementation procedures of the MAE approach

Comparing Fig. 2 with Fig. 3, the main differences between the LUT approach and the MAE approach are in the phase of estimating π(β). Consequently, the functional forms of the posterior distributions of β are different. However, the core idea (i.e. the switch mechanism of π(β) upon environmental changes) keeps the same.

sec.title: 3 EVALUATION AND ANALYSIS
sec.p: This section evaluates the LUT approach and the MAE approach through several numerical experiments designed based on the real degradation data of BGA solder joints collected in the recent tests. The data source and simulation design are introduced in Subsection 3.1. The experimental results and the associated analysis are given in Subsection 3.2.

sec.title: 3.1 Data source and simulation design
sec.p:
This subsection introduces the data source and simulation design for quantitative analysis of the LUT approach and the MAE approach. The entire structure of data source and simulation design is summarized in Fig. 4. Fig. 4
Data source and simulation design for quantitative evaluation and analysis of the LUT approach and the MAE approach, where πg(βk) denotes thegenerating distribution of β under environmental condition k

The simulation design is generally motivated by the availability of the degradation data (dynamic voltage) of BGA solder joints with various but not time-varying environmental conditions (mean vibration power spectral density [PSD]), which is obtained in our recent test. The basic idea is to fit the distribution of the stochastic degradation rate (πg(βk)) from these real degradation data as the first step. In this step, the parameter estimation algorithm in equation (3) is used, as each BGA package undergoes a consistent environmental condition throughout its lifetime. In this way, the stochastic degradation rate of the BGA packages under each environmental condition can be estimated, which captures the nature of the degradation processes of BGA packages.

In the second step, the close-to-reality degradation data under time-varying environmental conditions is simulated by mixing the degradation rates under different environmental conditions. Specifically, the degradation signals of each BGA package are modelled as (27) where βg4 is the stochastic degradation rate with distribution πg(β4), βge is the stochastic degradation rate with distribution πg(βe), e∈(1,2,3), and the rest model parameters are to be defined later. L is defined so that most samples undergo two environmental conditions before failure. In this way, the close-to-reality training and testing degradation data with time-varying environmental conditions is simulated. Note that for the training data, the data with mean PSD = 160 m2/s3 is not included to check the capability of the MAE approach for RL prediction in presence of a new environmental condition.

In the following, a brief summary of the experimental set-up and process is provided for readability. A more detailed description is given in reference [23]. Recently, a set of vibration tests were conducted to investigate the reliability characteristics of lead-free BGA solder joints under vibration environments. Typical BGA packages mounted on PCB board were used in the vibration test. For each PCB, eight BGA packages were mounted centro-symetrically, as shown in Fig. 5. An overview of the experimental set-up is shown in Fig. 6. Fig. 5
Round test board Fig. 6
An overview of the experimental set-up of the vibration tests, where Item 1: round test board,2: accelerometer, 3: charge amplifier, 4: LMS Test Lab, 5: interface of LMS Test Lab, 6: vibrator, 7: wires (for linking the daisy chain loop with the external resistor), 8: external resistor (R0), 9: recorder, and 10: cable of the recorder (for measuring the voltage across the resistor R0)

For the purpose of monitoring, a daisy chain loop was designed into each BGA connecting the critical solder joints [24]. In the experimental preparation phase, an external power supply and a resistance (Item 8 in Fig. 6) were connected into the daisy chain loop in series. During the tests, a recorder (Item 9 in Fig. 6) was used to record and display the dynamic voltage across the external resistance. The principle of the monitoring system can be shown in Fig. 7. As shown in Fig. 7, the voltage V0 across the external resistor R0 (≫ Rx) is E[R0/(R0 + Rx)]. Once any solder joint in the daisy chain loop breaks, Rx would be close to infinite (open circuit) and consequently V0 would be very close to zero. Fig. 7
Principle of the monitoring system, where Rx is the equivalent resistance for the daisy chain loop linking the solder joints in series, E is the voltage (–5V for recording convenience in the experiment) of the DC power supply

In each test, the vibrator was controlled by the LMS Test Lab (Item 4 in Fig. 6) to vibrate within a narrow frequency band containing the first natural frequency of the PCB, with a specified mean PSD. Altogether, we have mean PSD = 160 m2/s3 for two PCBs, mean PSD = 120 m2/s3 for two PCBs, mean PSD = 80 m2/s3 for two PCBs, and mean PSD = 60 m2/s3 for one PCB. The duration of each test was controlled so that most BGA packages failed during that test. Note that the failure of one BGA package can be observed from the dynamic voltage displayed by the recorder. Atypical degradation process of BGA packages with mean PSD = 80 m2/s3 is illustrated in Fig. 8. Fig. 8
A typical degradation process (solid black line) of BGA packages with mean PSD = 80 m2/s3

A close look at the degradation process of each BGA package reveals that there are mainly four phases forthe recorded dynamic voltage. In Phase 1, the dynamic voltage varies stably around –5V, and this corresponds to the stable phase of the BGA package. When crack initiates in the critical solder joints, it is noticed that there exits an abrupt increase of the dynamic voltage for almost all BGA packages, and this process is denoted as Phase 2. Afterwards, the dynamic voltage enters Phase 3, and increases gradually until it reaches the critical level (zero voltage). Finally, in Phase 4, the BGA package fails and the dynamic voltage varies around the critical level. We are interested in Phase 3, which corresponds to the degradation process of BGA packages. As shown in Fig. 8, it is reasonable to model the evolution of the dynamic voltage by a linear degradation model.

By checking closely the second phase of each BGA package, it is observed that Phase 2 usually ends with V0 ≈ –4V. For simplicity, –4V is designated as the change point between Phases 2 and 3 and ϵ = 0 is assumed for the point V0 = –4V [5]. To estimate πg(βk) under each mean PSD, it is necessary to estimate σϵ first. Following the method in [5], we haveσϵ = 0.1112. Afterwards, the prior distribution πg(βk) can be estimated based on equation (3). The stochastic liner degradation model for Phase 3 under each mean PSD is characterized in Table 1. Table 1
The stochastic linear degradation model for Phase 3 of the degradation processes of BGA packages
Model parameters/mean PSD (m2/s3) 160 210 80 60
Sample number 16 16 16 8
φ –4
β μβ 0.1713 0.1436 0.1259 0.1070
σβ 0.1086 0.1034 0.0831 0.0529
σɛ 0.1112

In Table 1, it is observed that the mean PSD does influence the degradation rate of BGA packages. Based on the stochastic linear degradation model in Table 1, the simulation information of the training data and the testing data are detailed in Table 2, which are further used to evaluate the LUT approach and the MAE approach. Table 2
Simulation details of the training data and the testing data
Simulation model L Sample number Approaches to be evaluated
Training data Eq. (28), e = 2, 3 15 50 /
Testing data Group 1 Eq. (28). e = 2, 3 15 50 LUT, MAE, SUDM
Group 2 Eq. (28), e = 1 15 25 MAE, SUDM

In Table 2, sensory-updated degradation model (SUDM) denotes the classical sensory-updating degradation model which simply ignores the effect of environmental conditions [5, 18]. In general, π(β) of the SUDM can be estimated in equation (3) based on all the historical training data, regardless of the different environmental conditions. Afterwards, given the in-situ degradation signals of an individual component, the SUDM can be updated based on equation (11). The RL/RLD prediction formula for the SUDM is also equation (19).

As mentioned before, for the training data, the degradation process under mean PSD = 160 m2/s3 is not simulated to evaluate the capability of the MAE approach of RL prediction when a new environmental condition is present. It is noted that two groups of testing data is simulated. The LUT approach, the MAE approach, and the SUDM approach are all applicable to the first group of testing data and consequently their performance can be compared simultaneously. The second group of testing data is generated to evaluate the performance of the MAE approach for RL prediction under an environmental condition not included in the historical training data. In addition, the simulation horizon is set to be long enough so that all the testing samples fail in the end, and consequently their exact failure times are known to evaluate the RL prediction accuracy. For illustration, two simulated degradation processes of testing samples are shown in Fig. 9. As shown in Fig. 9, testing sample A is from the first group of testing data with mean PSD = 120 m2/s3 after L = 15 and testing sample B is from the first group of testing data with mean PSD = 80 m2/s3 after L = 15. Fig 9
Two simulated degradation processes of testing samples

In the next subsection, the simulated training data will be used for estimating the prior distribution of the degradation rate under various environmental conditions, by equations (8) or (25). Afterwards, the simulated testing data will be used to evaluate the performance of RL prediction by several approaches (shown in Table 2).

sec.title: 3.2 Results and analysis
sec.p: This subsection presents the evaluation results basedon the simulated training and testing degradation processes with time-varying environmental conditions.

To implement the RL approaches, it is necessary to estimate the prior distribution of the degradation rate π(βk) first. π(βk) for the LUT approach can be estimated based on equation (8) and the simulated training data. π(βk) for the MAE approach can be estimated based on equations (24) to (25) and the simulated training data. π(βk) for the SUDM approach can be estimated based on equation (3) and the simulated training data. The estimation results are summarized in Table 3. Table 3
The estimated prior distribution of the degradation rate under each environmental condition for the LUT approach, the MAE approach, and the classical SUDM approach
Approach/mean PSD (m2/s3) 160 120 80 60
LUT μ∧β / 0.1422 0.1066 0.1037
σ∧β / 0.0981 0.0685 0.0377
MAE μ∧β 0.1087 0.1067 0.1047 0.1037
σ∧β 0.1440 0.0842 0.0493 0.0377
SUDM μ∧β 0.1073
σ∧β 0.0492

Note that in Table 3, the reference environmental condition is chosen to be: mean PSD = 60 m2/s3, and it is estimated that α∧=0.00047 and λ∧=0.0268. After the prior distributions π(βk) have been estimated, the approaches in Table 2 can be implemented for RL prediction based on their respective updating mechanisms (i.e. equation (15) for the LUT approach, equation (26) for the MAE approach, and equation (11) for the SUDM approach).
To analyse the prediction accuracy by the approaches in Table 2, the prediction error is defined as the percentile difference between the actual and predicted failure times [13]
where PE(ti) denotes the prediction error (PE) at time ti, PRL(ti) denotes the predicted RL at time ti, and F denotes the actual failure time.

For intuition, the PEs calculated at the jth percentile of the lifetime of testing sample A (shown in Fig. 9) are demonstrated in Fig. 10, where j = 10,20,…,90. Fig. 10
PEs versus degradation percentile for testing sample A

In Fig. 10, the three approaches have very similar performance before the environmental condition changes. However, the LUT approaches and the MAE approaches clearly outperform the classical SUDM approach after the environmental condition change by providing more accurate predictions. Significantly more accurate RL is predicted by the LUT approach and the MAE approach when it is close to failure (i.e. 90 per cent degradation percentile).

To gain insight into the proposed updating mechanism in equations (15) and (26), the updated posterior values μ~βkn and σ~βkn throughout the lifetime of testing sample A are calculated at each sampling point. Figure 11 shows the μ~βkn and σ~βkn by the LUT approach, equation (15). Note that the updating mechanism of the MAE approach is very similar. Fig. 11
Posterior values μ~βkn and σ~βkn throughout the lifetime of testing sample A by the LUT approach

A close look at equation (15) reveals that the updating mechanism begins to work when the degradation signals at two consecutive sampling points are collected under the same environmental condition. As shown in Fig. 11, at time t = 10s and 160s when the degradation signal at only one sampling point is available under one environmental condition, the prior values are used as estimated in Table 3. As shown in Fig. 11, the oscillatory characteristics of μ~βkn can generally be attributed to the fluctuation nature of the degradation signals. On the other hand, the abrupt increase of σ~βkn at time t = 160s is due to the environmental condition change at time t = 150s. As the degradation signals before the environmental condition change cannot be used to update σβkn, the estimation of the degradation rate is very uncertain upon encountering a new environmental condition. However, the estimation uncertainty reduces gradually when more and more degradation signals under the same environmental conditions are collected.

Next, statistical analysis is performed for the prediction results based on the testing data in Groups 1 and 2. The mean PEs based on the 50 testing samples in Group 1 are shown in Fig. 12. Fig. 12
Mean PEs versus degradation percentile for all the 50 testing samples in Group 1

Based on the results in Fig. 12 and Table 4, it is observed that both the LUT approach and the MAE approach outperform the classical SUDM approach by providing smaller mean PEs and narrower 95 per cent CIs, especially when the components have median or high-degradation percentile. This provides evidence that both the LUT approach and the MAE approach can give more accurate and reliable RL prediction in time-varying environments. In addition, the LUT approach performs slightly better than the MAE approach. This can be attributed to the fact that the LUT approach naturally models the effect of environmental conditions without imposing any artificial term on the stochastic linear degradation model in equation (1), while the MAE approach uses the prior knowledge that the environmental conditions have a multiplicative acceleration/deceleration effect on component degradation rate, which might be true or untrue. Thus, in general, the LUT can better characterize the effect of environmental conditions, reflected by a closer match between the estimated π(βk) in Table 3 and the generating distribution in Table 2. Analysis of the loading profile of each testing sample in Group 1 reveals that all the samples enter a new environmental condition (i.e. mean PSD = 80 or 120 m2/s3) after 30 per cent of their lifetimes. Consequently, the LUT approach and the MAE approach performs equally before 30 per cent degradation percentile, as they use the same π(βk) for mean PSD = 60 m2/s3.

Although the LUT approach slightly outperforms the MAE approach based on the testing data in Group 1, it is limited by the requirement that the training data ideally covers all possible environmental conditions. The MAE approach does not have such limitation and can be used for RL prediction under anew environmental condition. Similar to Fig. 12, Fig. 13 shows the tendency of the mean PEs based on the 25 testing samples in Group 2 to study the performance of the MAE approach when a new environmental condition (i.e. mean PSD = 160 m2/s3) is present. Fig. 13
Mean PEs versus degradation percentile for all the 25 testing samples in Group 2
The 95 per cent CIs for the PEs based on the testing samples in Group 2 are summarized in Table 2.

Based on the results in Fig. 13 and Table 5, the MAE approach still have clear superiority over the classical SUDM approach when a new environmental condition is present. And this provides evidence that the MAE approach can be used even when only limited environmental conditions are covered by the historical training data. Although the estimated prior distribution of the degradation rate with mean PSD = 120 m2/s3 in Table 3 is not very close to the associated generating distribution in Table 2, the MAE approach still outperforms the classical SUDM approach by distinguishing the sampling points under different environmental conditions for model update (shown in Fig. 3), as opposed to simply mixing all sampling points by the classical SUDM approach. Table 5
Statistical analysis of the PE for the 25 testing samples in Group 2
Degradation percentile (%) 10 20 30
MAE 95% CI [–2.4541, 3.7099] [–0.9895, 0.6539] [–1.0190, 1.5727]
SUDM 95% CI [–9.3776, 12.3452] [–1.0534, 1.6303] [–1.0384, 1.5974]
Degradation percentile (%) 40 50 60
MAE 95% CI [–0.4749, 0.6539] [–0.4582, 0.6306] [–0.2882, 0.5310]
SUDM 95% CI [–0.9498, 1.5032] [–0.5878, 0.9954] [–0.4991, 0.7884]
Degradation percentile (%) 70 80 90
MAE 95% CI [–0.2183, 0.3219] [–0.1879, 0.1776] [–0.0941, 0.0557]
SUDM 95% CI [–0.3119, 0.5196] [–0.2205, 0.3010] [–0.1104, 0.1554]

sec.title: 4 CONCLUDING REMARKS
sec.p: This article proposes two approaches for modelling the effect of time-varying environmental conditions on the degradation processes of systems subject to linear/exponential degradation, and derives the procedures for applying the approaches to real-time component RL prediction. The LUT approach accesses the effect of environmental conditions empirically from historical training data. The MAE approach regards that environmental condition has a multiplicative acceleration/deceleration effect on component degradation rate.

The experimental results demonstrate clear superiority of the LUT approach and the MAE approach over the classical SUDM approach which simply ignores the effect of environmental conditions. When both applicable, the LUT approach slightly outperforms the MAE approach. However, the LUT is limited by the requirement that all possible finite environmental conditions are covered by the training data. The MAE approach does not have such limitation and can handle new environmental conditions. Evidence has been gained that the MAE approach still performs well when a new environmental condition is present.

In the future, it is necessary to benchmark the LUT approach and the MAE approach with the existing approaches to RL prediction in time-varying environments. It would also be valuable to integrate the RL prediction approaches with a CBM model to investigate the impact of environmental conditions on the performance of a CBM policy. It is certainly valuable to explore other perspectives on EEM.
